qas.question: What expedition did Darwin join in 1831?
Who wrote The Principles of Geology?
Where was the first stop of the Beagle Expedition?
What did some of the fossils Darwin found on St. Jago resemble?
What caused Darwin to change his mind about the unbridgeable gap between animals and humans?

answers.text: their relatives on the island seemed "miserable, degraded savages"

context: In December 1831, he joined the <a0_0>Beagle expedition<a0_0/> as a gentleman naturalist and geologist. He read <a1_0>Charles Lyell<a1_0/>'s Principles of Geology and from the first stop ashore, at <a2_0>St. Jago<a2_0/>, found Lyell's uniformitarianism a key to the geological history of landscapes. Darwin discovered fossils resembling <a3_0>huge armadillos<a3_0/>, and noted the geographical distribution of modern species in hope of finding their "centre of creation". The three Fuegian missionaries the expedition returned to Tierra del Fuego were friendly and civilised, yet to Darwin <a4_0>their relatives on the island seemed "miserable, degraded savages"<a4_0/>, and he no longer saw an unbridgeable gap between humans and animals. As the Beagle neared England in 1836, he noted that species might not be fixed.
